I'm reading a terribly sad book these da:
I'm reading a terribly sad book these days. It's called The Book of Lost Things by John Connolly and it's about the loss, not only in death but also from life itself.
The story is told through two voices: that which tells us what happened to Billy's things after he died (and how they were found); then there are letters written between his mother Helen who still lives on Earth with her husband George as well their daughter Rose - all three grieving for him deeply even though he's been gone now over twenty years...

That is the "Blade Runner" problem. It has been solved in many ways, but it still remains a difficult issue.
The first solution was to use an external database and keep track of all objects that have changed since last time you ran your application (and thus need reloading). This works fine for small applications with few changes between runs - or if you're willing/able/captain obvious enough not change anything during runtime. 
But what about larger projects? What happens when there are hundreds/millions/billions/trilliards...of things changing at any given moment?
A second approach would be some kind on versioning system

There are varying explanations. Some say that the name comes from a word meaning “high place” or “hill," which is also how it was spelled in Old English.
Others believe it’s derived either directly (via Latin) of Gaulish *gallo-(“hill people”; compare modern French gaillard), ultimately related to Proto-Celtic *skal-/*sgal-“hilly ground; mountainous region";
or via an intermediate form gallia > gallaica "of Gallia" and then by extension "highlands" as used for parts outside Wales.

Is it possible to protect e-mails agains:
Is it possible to protect e-mails against being read? Is there a way for me, as the sender of an e-mail message (in this case I am using gmail), can be sure that my recipient will not have access or view any content in plain text?
I know about PGP encryption but I'm wondering if there's something simpler and more user friendly.

A:

You can't. If you want your email encrypted then use GPG/PGPMIME.
If you're worried someone might intercept/read/sniff emails on their network connection they could just install wireshark/tcpdump/wireshake etc...

Nobody can answer the questions about wh:
Nobody can answer the questions about why this happens. But we know that it does happen, and there are many people who have experienced these things.
There is a great deal of evidence to suggest they do not exist at all – but I am sure you will find plenty if researching on your own…
I think what’s happening here (and in other cases) may be something like this: A person has an experience which seems real enough for them personally; however when asked “Isn’t everything just imagination?” their response becomes “I don’t believe so!”; or perhaps more accurately:
“Yes…it was my mind playing games with me again
